column3: lit. old oak) is a town in Bryansk Oblast
column5: located on the Babinets River (the Dnieper basin)
column6: 169 kilometers (105 mi) southwest of Bryansk. Population: 19

column1: Starodub has been known since the 11th century
column2: when it was a part of Severia. It was burned to the ground by the Mongols in the 13th century. It became a part of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania in the 14th century
column3: and later the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth. In 1503–1618
column4: Starodub was a part of the Grand Duchy of Moscow and then Commonwealth until 1648. During the Khmelnytskyi Uprising
column6: and 188 families of local Ruthenian nobility recognized the Ukrainian hetman as a new governor. Starodub became the center of Starodub Cossack Regiment and enjoyed a large measure of autonomy between 1666 and 1686.

column1: Starodub remained rudiments of Cossack Hetmanate's administrative division until 1782 when it became an uyezd town. In 1796
column2: Starodub was incorporated into Chernigov Governorate. In 1918
column3: the town was occupied by the Germans. The Soviet authority was reinstated in November 1918.

column2: Starodub was a part of Gomel Governorate (1919–1926)
column5: and Oryol Oblast (1937–1944). The town was once again occupied by the Germans between August 18
column7: 1943. Starodub finally became a part of Bryansk Oblast in 1944.

column1: Within the framework of administrative divisions
column2: Starodub serves as the administrative center of Starodubsky District
column3: even though it is not a part of it. As an administrative division
column4: it is incorporated separately as Starodubsky Urban Administrative Okrug—an administrative unit with the status equal to that of the districts. As a municipal division
column5: Starodubsky Urban Administrative Okrug is incorporated as Starodub Urban Okrug.Prior to January 1
column7: Starodub was administratively incorporated as a town of district significance within Starodubsky District.

column1: As a significant center of the Cossack Hetmanate
column2: Starodub is the only place in Russia where authentic examples of Ukrainian Baroque may be seen. The Nativity Cathedral
column3: built in 1617 and overhauled after a conflagration in 1677
column4: is a typical example of Cossack Baroque. The Epiphany Church goes back to 1789
column5: while the Church of St. Nicholas was erected in the Neoclassical style in 1802.
